sub_topic: Probability of a certain event occurring in a given time period
message_1: A manufacturer of light bulbs knows that the probability of a bulb lasting more than 1000 hours is 0.7. What is the probability that out of 10 bulbs produced, exactly 7 will last more than 1000 hours?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the binomial probability formula:

P(X = k) = C(n, k) * p^k * (1-p)^(n-k)

where:
- P(X = k) is the probability of exactly k successes (in this case, bulbs lasting more than 1000 hours)
- C(n, k) is the number of combinations of n items taken k at a time (also written as nCk or "n choose k")
- n is the total number of trials (in this case, 10 bulbs)
- k is the number of successes (in this case, 7 bulbs lasting more than 1000 hours)
- p is the probability of a single success (in this case, 0.7)
- (1-p) is the probability of a single failure (in this case, 0.3)

Plugging in the values for this problem:

P(X = 7) = C(10, 7) * 0.7^7 * 0.3^3

First, we calculate C(10, 7), which is the number of ways to choose 7 bulbs out of 10:

C(10, 7) = 10! / (7! * (10-7)!)
C(10, 7) = 10! / (7! * 3!)
C(10, 7) = 3628800 / (5040 * 6)
C(10, 7) = 3628800 / 30240
C(10, 7) = 120

Now, we can plug this value back into the binomial probability formula:

P(X = 7) = 120 * 0.7^7 * 0.3^3

Calculating the probabilities:

0.7^7 = 0.0823543
0.3^3 = 0.027

Now, multiply all the values together:

P(X = 7) = 120 * 0.0823543 * 0.027
P(X = 7) â‰ˆ 0.2668

So, the probability that exactly 7 out of 10 bulbs will last more than 1000 hours is approximately 0.2668 or 26.68%.
